title.value: Normalizing Flow Ensembles for Rich Aleatoric and Epistemic Uncertainty Modeling
title.justification: This is a direct extraction of the title from the given research paper.
title.quote: Normalizing Flow Ensembles for Rich Aleatoric and Epistemic Uncertainty Modeling

extractions.description: This paper proposes the use of Normalizing Flows (NFs) ensembles to estimate both epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty in dynamic systems. The authors introduce two methods, Nflows Out and Nflows Base, which utilize fixed dropout masks in order to form the ensembles. They further demonstrate the application of these methods in a range of experiments and benchmark datasets to validate the efficiency and uncertainty quantification.

type.justification: The paper contains experimental results, empirical validations, and comparison with baseline models, showcasing practical applications and performance metrics.
type.quote: The methods were applied to a variety of experiments, commonly used to benchmark aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation.

name.justification: The core focus of the paper is on estimating both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty using deep learning techniques, particularly Normalizing Flows.
name.quote: In this work, we demonstrate how to reliably estimate epistemic uncertainty while maintaining the flexibility needed to capture complicated aleatoric distributions.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses and utilizes Normalizing Flows, a type of deep learning model for uncertainty estimation.
name.quote: Normalizing Flows (NFs) have been shown to be effective at capturing highly expressive aleatoric uncertainty with little prior knowledge.

name.justification: The paper employs an active learning framework to iteratively collect data in order to improve the models.
name.quote: In these experiments, we setup an active learning framework and evaluate each model’s capability at measuring aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty.

name.justification: The proposed methodologies involve creating ensembles of models using dropout masks to estimate epistemic uncertainty.
name.quote: The ensembles are created via sets of fixed dropout masks, making them less expensive than creating separate NF models.

name.justification: One of the two main methods proposed in the paper for estimating uncertainty using ensembles of Normalizing Flows.
name.quote: Nflows Out: creates an ensemble in the nonlinear transformations g’s.

is_contributed.justification: The model is introduced as a novel contribution in the presented work.
is_contributed.quote: We propose two approaches for creating NF ensembles, Nflows Out and Nflows Base.

is_executed.justification: The paper contains empirical results showing the application and execution of Nflows Out in various experiments.
is_executed.quote: Using Nflows Out, we can approximate Equation (1). We employ Monte Carlo sampling to estimate the quantities of interest.

is_compared.justification: Nflows Out is compared to multiple baseline models to evaluate its performance.
is_compared.quote: We have included several baselines and compared each method’s ability to measure aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Nflows Out is a novel model proposed in this paper, hence there is no referenced paper title.

name.justification: The second main method proposed for creating Normalizing Flows ensembles to efficiently quantify uncertainty.
name.quote: Nflows Base: the bijective mapping is static for each component while the base distribution varies.

is_contributed.justification: The model is introduced as a novel contribution in the presented work.
is_contributed.quote: We propose two approaches for creating NF ensembles, Nflows Out and Nflows Base.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes experimental results involving the execution of Nflows Base.
is_executed.quote: Nflows Base has advantages when estimating uncertainty as the component variability is contained in the base distribution.

is_compared.justification: Nflows Base is compared against multiple baseline models to evaluate its performance.
is_compared.quote: We have included several baselines and compared each method’s ability to measure aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Nflows Base is a novel model proposed in this paper, hence there is no referenced paper title.

name.justification: This dataset is explicitly mentioned as one of the test data used to benchmark the proposed methods for uncertainty estimation.
name.quote: The methods were applied to a variety of experiments, commonly used to benchmark aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation: 1D sinusoidal data.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset seems to be generated for the purposes of this study and is not referenced from another paper.

name.justification: This dataset is used as one of the benchmarks for testing the proposed methods.
name.quote: The methods were applied to a variety of experiments, commonly used to benchmark aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation: ... 2D windy grid-world (Wet Chicken).

referenced_paper_title.justification: Wet Chicken is a well-known benchmark environment and hence does not correspond to a specific referenced paper in this contexts.

name.justification: This dataset refers to an environment commonly used as a testbed for control and reinforcement learning problems.
name.quote: The methods were applied to a variety of experiments, commonly used to benchmark aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation: ... Pendulum.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Pendulum is referenced as a generic test environment and does not correspond to a specific referenced paper.

name.justification: This dataset is used as one of the benchmark environments to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.
name.quote: The methods were applied to a variety of experiments, commonly used to benchmark aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation: ... Hopper.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Hopper is referenced as a generic test environment and does not correspond to a specific referenced paper.

name.justification: PyTorch is a widely used deep learning library and is mentioned as the base framework for experiments.
name.quote: Both openai gym and nflows libraries were utilized with minor changes (Brockman et al. 2016; Durkan et al. 2020).

referenced_paper_title.justification: PyTorch is referenced as the deep learning framework for implementing the experiments, not associated with another specific reference.

name.justification: Nflows is explicitly mentioned as the library used to implement the Normalizing Flows in the experiments.
name.quote: Both openai gym and nflows libraries were utilized with minor changes (Brockman et al. 2016; Durkan et al. 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: Neural Spline Flows. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, volume 32
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the proper citation for the Nflows library used in the experiments.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Durkan, C.; Bekasov, A.; Murray, I.; and Papamakarios, G. 2019b. Neural Spline Flows. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, volume 32.
